title: High Public Debt Service Burden
description: In 2023, Angola's public and publicly guaranteed debt service reached 13.84% of its GNI, indicating a significant financial burden on the country's economy.

title: Low Educational Attainment
description: By 2021, only 0.13% of Angola's population aged 25 and above had attained at least a Bachelor's degree, reflecting a challenge in higher education access.

title: High Out-of-Pocket Health Expenditure
description: In 2018, 35.53% of Angola's population spent more than 10% of their household income on health care, highlighting a significant financial strain on citizens.

title: Significant Net Liabilities
description: In 2017, Angola's net incurrence of liabilities was 20.42% of its GDP, indicating a substantial financial obligation for the country.

title: High Cost of Sending Remittances
description: In 2021, the average transaction cost of sending remittances from Angola was 16.86%, one of the highest globally, affecting financial inclusivity.

title: Low Female Educational Attainment
description: As of 2019, only 0.036% of females aged 25 and above in Angola had attained at least a Bachelor's degree, indicating gender disparities in education.

title: Dependence on Private Creditors
description: In 2023, Angola's net financial liabilities to private creditors stood at -$2.71 billion, reflecting a reliance on external private financing.

title: Limited Domestic Economic Claims
description: In 2023, claims on other sectors of Angola's domestic economy were only 10.12% of GDP, suggesting limited internal financial intermediation.

title: Low Multilateral Debt Service
description: In 2023, only 3.54% of Angola's public debt service was multilateral, indicating a lower reliance on international financial institutions.

title: Negative Aid Flow from Portugal
description: In 2022, Angola experienced a net negative bilateral aid flow of -$52.73 million from Portugal, impacting its foreign aid receipts.
